title: 110_hr7008
content: The Act titled "Low-Income Rate Payer Disaster Recovery Act of 2008" focuses on repairing, restoring, and replacing damaged facilities of electric utility companies serving low-income households. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to allow contributions to electric utility companies serving low-income households for repair and restoration of facilities damaged by a major disaster. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to allow contributions to private or investor-owned electric utility companies serving low-income households for repair and restoration of facilities damaged by a major disaster. The President may provide assistance only if the costs exceed 10 percent of the facilities' value. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to allow contributions to private or investor-owned electric utility companies for repair and restoration of facilities damaged by a major disaster. Assistance may be provided if costs exceed 10 percent of the facilities' total transmission and distribution rate base, with considerations for accumulated depreciation. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act allows contributions to electric utility companies for repairing facilities damaged by disasters. Costs from previous disasters within 12 months before the current disaster declaration can be aggregated. Application deadlines for assistance are within 60 months of the disaster declaration date. An owner or operator seeking contributions for disaster relief must apply within 60 months of the most recent major disaster. The funding amount is determined by the difference in costs attributable to the owner or operator and the percent of low-income households among retail residential customers. The total amount of contributions for disaster relief to an owner or operator may not exceed $50,000,000 in any 12-month period, with a presidential waiver available for extraordinary events. The total amount of contributions for disaster relief to an owner or operator may not exceed $50,000,000 in any 12-month period, with a presidential waiver available for extraordinary events. Contributions under paragraph (1)(C) cannot exceed 100 percent of the cost of repair, restoration, reconstruction, or replacement of damaged facilities. The President must approve or disapprove applications for contributions within 30 days of receipt. The Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to include private or investor-owned electric utility companies serving low-income households for assistance. This allows for contributions to these companies for repair, restoration, reconstruction, or replacement of damaged facilities. Private or investor-owned electric utility companies serving low-income households may receive a contribution equal to 75 percent of available funding for repairing, restoring, or improving power facilities. The funds can also be used for constructing new facilities or funding hazard mitigation measures. Private or investor-owned electric utility companies serving low-income households may receive a contribution for repairing, restoring, or improving power facilities. The funds can also be used for constructing new facilities or funding hazard mitigation measures. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to include private or investor-owned electric utility companies in eligible costs. Definitions for private or investor-owned electric utility companies are provided in the Act. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms related to private or investor-owned electric utility companies serving low-income households, including what constitutes a company, an electric utility company, and a low-income household. The curr_chunk defines income thresholds for low-income households based on state poverty levels and median income. It references definitions from the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Act of 1981. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Chairman of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, must create regulations within 180 days of this Act's enactment to implement the Act and its amendments. The Act and its amendments apply to major disasters occurring after the Act's enactment.
